title: Video Stream Analytics for Viewers in the TV Industry
segmentation: So I will.
I'll talk about feature TV, which I mean the whole theme of the call was bootstrapping the data economy and this is in particular on the IPTV.
So Internet TV data economy.
So what is the starting?

And for this particular project, so the observation the key observation underlying this project is that the companies that do IPTV actually gather user data that is extremely interesting and potentially extremely valuable.
So traditionally this kind of data is being gathered by this rating.
Companies that have panels of people who rate.
Particular programs in India's news set up with IPTV you get lots and lots more data.
OK, it's not yet everybody reduce it, but it goes now into the millions, so there's a lot of potential actually within this consortium.
When we're setting up the proposal, we had discussions on how it should be exploited, so should only be mean that there's a clear commercial value there.
I'll show that later in the stream, but it's also a clear public value there, so we decided actually to do both.
Both have a part that goes a data pool that is meant for.
Commercial commercial exploitation that's really grouped around user data and another part that's for public open source consumption, which is program data.
OK, so how does this work?
So we have a number of these sort of the two parents in there who who do who provides.
IP.
TV and we are interested in providing generating two data pools.
One is on user behavior of.
TV viewers and the 2nd is data that we want to publish on the web on programs.
OK, so.
Of course, in some cases, in particular of the SMB enforcer two, that's IP provider day.
Get their original data from broadcasters.
So to have all this data typically also some program metadata, BBC already actually publishes most of this and would one of our main task will be to do processing of their data.
So a lot of machine learning goes in here, feature extraction and so on, and that will give us a large data warehouse an from that we want to feed these two data pools.
OK, so that's the core simple baseline of the project.
So we do in a few additional things.
So that that user behavior data that's being funneled back to?
People are interested in receiving these data, so that could include the original broadcasters, advertisers, but also the rating companies.
The public sector.
Of course we will contribute to the web.
And of course, that kind of data can also be used to do better processing of the data.
And a third final stream that we are interested in is providing providing also recommendations that you can generate from this data warehouse.
And those recommendations you can then feedback.
So that's one of the applications we're going to develop is develop an application that consumers can use.
To watch IPTV online so the various issues involved there but in effect this will give us another source of data that we can use in our tagging.
So one feature of this is this all needs to be done real time.
Well what we called quasi real time in TV that's deley 5 seconds is seen as life's real time so this is real time processing of lots of data.
So that means every hour you process like 10 to 60 gigabytes of.
The data that you get in so does that.
That's one aspect.
So it so this is a whole streaming process.
OK, that's actually what I want to say about the project, so these activities are part of our project and we have.
First website running.
And we started 1st of June.
So that's last week we have our kickoff next week.
Thank you for your attention.
